Question: cyclic traversal over enum: :what is the best way of cyclic traversal over an enum.I have an enum Directions and i want to traverse over it cyclically. currently i have implemented next method in enum which returns next value, i was just wondering is there any better way/inbuilt support for cyclic traversal.current codeenum Direction {    east, north, west, south;    Direction next() {        switch (this) {        case east:            return north;        case north:            return west;        case west:            return south;        case south:            return east;        }        return null;    }}
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: cyclic traversal over enum: :what is the best way of cyclic traversal over an enum.I have an enum Directions and i want to traverse over it cyclically. currently i have implemented next method in enum which returns next value, i was just wondering is there any better way/inbuilt support for cyclic traversal.current codeenum Direction {    east, north, west, south;    Direction next() {        switch (this) {        case east:            return north;        case north:            return west;        case west:            return south;        case south:            return east;        }        return null;    }}
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: <<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
```java
Iterator<Direction> iterator = Arrays.asList(Direction.values()).iterator();
Direction next = iterator.next(); // returns first element
Direction nextCyclic = iterator.next(); // returns second element, and so on
```
<<<explanation>>>: The `Arrays.asList(Direction.values()).iterator()` creates an iterator over the values of the enum. The `iterator.next()` method returns the next element in the iteration. When the iteration is finished, it starts again from the beginning. This is exactly what you want for cyclic traversal.

Note: This approach assumes that you want to traverse the enum values in the order they are declared in the enum. If you want to traverse in a different order, you will need to manage the order yourself.
<|EOT|>
